awd_titl_txt: Building Efficiency for a Sustainable Tomorrow (BEST) Center
awd_abstract_narration:
Commercial buildings are a predominant feature of U.S. cities that account for almost 20% of greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs) in the U.S. There is increased pressure in the U.S. to reduce GHG emissions and conserve non-renewable energy resources that is leading to a need to reduce the consumption of energy in commercial buildings. At the same time, research on Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) certified buildings suggests that improved indoor environmental quality increases worker productivity. The federal Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) estimates that there are 292,000 "HVAC Mechanics and Installers" employed in the U.S. and that the field will add almost 40,000 new positions between 2014 and 2024, a much faster than average rate of growth. A study for the HVACR Workforce Development foundation estimates that 70% of openings in the field are middle skill jobs requiring postsecondary education and that the demand for these workers outstrips supply. To address these issues, it is necessary to educate a workforce of Building Automation Systems (BAS) Specialists as well as High Performance Building Operations Professionals (HPBOP). The Building Efficiency for a Sustainable Tomorrow (BEST) Center will focus on growing its national network of community and technical colleges interested in improving and/or developing new building science technician education programs. 

The BEST Center proposes to serve as a national vehicle for the collection, dissemination, and adoption of responsive, timely, and exceptional educational programs, courses, lab applications, and innovative instructional methods for the education of building systems technicians. This project outlines three goals: 1) Transform the instructional capacity of community colleges in the field of building technician education, with an emphasis on HPBOP and BAS training and certification; 2) Engage industry stakeholders and research partners in a national collaboration with community colleges to support high quality building science instructional programs; and, 3) Strengthen the national STEM pipeline for building technicians, focusing on outreach to both high school students and underrepresented adult learners. The Center will continue to archive model curriculum and disseminate and promote adoption of this model curriculum nationwide.

Building Efficiency for a Sustainable Tomorrow (BEST): National Center & Project Outcomes 2017-24

The BEST Center, established as a National Center in 2012 with support from the National Science Foundation (NSF), has become a leader in educating high-performance building technicians. Its mission focuses on preparing students for careers in commercial building operations, aiming to improve building performance and promote environmental sustainability. Together with community and technical colleges, industry partners, and STEM organizations, BEST has advanced the career pathway for building engineers and technicians.

In 2017, BEST received a five-year, $3.6 million NSF renewal grant, enabling the Center to expand its efforts with partners Laney College, Georgia Piedmont Technical College (GPTC), Milwaukee Area Technical College (MATC), and Lawrence Berkeley National Lab (LBNL). Later in 2021, the grant was transferred to UC Berkeley, which became the new fiscal agent. From 2022-2024, two no-cost extensions and a supplemental award were granted to focus on BEST's professional certification project (details provided later in this report).

Curriculum and Resources

BEST offers model curricula and resources in Building Automation Systems (BAS), Commercial HVAC, Energy Auditing, and Sustainable Facilities Operations on its website (www.bestctr.org). These include instructional lab videos, LBNL energy management tools, and sample marketing materials, as well as a YouTube channel that archives all workshop and webinar recordings.

Professional Development and Technical Assistance

Through advanced education for instructors, BEST has built a network of over 70 active community and technical colleges. During the first five years of the grant, BEST hosted 5 National Institutes, 5 BAS workshops, and 9 webinars, which helped boost the adoption of its curriculum and resources:

  • Over 600 faculty (duplicate count) from 40 states participated in BEST events to learn about advancements in building technologies and project-based learning strategies.
  • At least 30 colleges integrated BAS content into their curricula, receiving technical support from BEST in setting up instructional labs and acquiring equipment.
  • During the COVID-19 pandemic, BEST shifted to virtual meetings and events, transforming the Institute into an online conference. Webinars focused on distance learning, creating virtual lab environments with 360-degree video, and home-based lab activities for students.

Industry Partnerships

Corporate support of college programs--both locally and nationally --provided an estimated value of $7.33 million to sustain these sources of skilled workers. Automated Logic, Computrols, Contemporary Controls, Honeywell, Rheem, Siemens, and others donated equipment or offered discounts for teaching labs. Many high-profile companies, agencies, and organizations also served as BEST advisors including Building Owners and Managers Association, CB/Richard Ellis, Department of Energy, International Facility Management Association, Jones Lang LaSalle, Marriott Hotels, and U.S. General Services Administration.

High-Performance Building Operations Professional (HPBOP) Certification

In order to recognize the professional value and technical proficiency of high-performance building technicians, BEST worked closely with industry experts to create the HPBOP certification program. In addition, BEST organized HPBOP classes for California technicians with funding from investor-owned utilities and the California Department of General Services. The feedback from 107 participants (2017-19) contributed further to the credential's development.

To roll out the program, an initial certification exam was offered at no-cost and promoted by industry partners in 2023. At the conclusion of this 15-month pilot phase, 36 candidates passed the test and were awarded the credential which must be renewed every 3 years. BEST is currently seeking ISO 17024 Certification Accreditation and completing curriculum guidance for colleges to align their program outcomes with HPBOP knowledge and skills. Information about the exam and eligibility can be found at www.hpbop.org. 

National Alliance for High-Performance Building Operations (NAHBO)

BEST established NAHBO, a 501(c)(3) organization that now owns the HPBOP certification and will succeed BEST. The organization received federal not-for-profit status in 2024.

Impact on Students and the Workforce (2017-2022)

During the first five years of the grant:

  • Over 7,000 college students took at least one course utilizing BEST resources.
  • More than 2,400 students completed BEST-related programs.
  • Approximately 2,300 students were placed into the workforce.

Additionally, BEST explored STEM collaborations with the national nonprofit ACE Mentor. The Oakland/East Bay chapter, hosted by BEST and Laney College in 2017-18, connected high school students, industry professionals and educators. Through after-school projects and campus tours, participants learned about careers in architecture, construction, engineering, and building trades. Elsewhere in the U.S., College of Southern Nevada and MATC made similar efforts to enhance their local connections with ACE.

BEST Resource Center Grant

In 2022, BEST was awarded a 3-year Resource Center Grant allowing its primary activities to continue until 2025. Reports for this award can be found under DUE 2202180.
